history.content: Don't think so – I know many people have done it, but you probably want to talk to your advisor to make sure that you'll be allowed re-entry in your specific case.

children.subject: I heard there's nothing really but probably just a bunch of tedious paperwork.
Haha yeah it's definitely an involved decision.

I did an internship over the fall semester about a year or two ago, and I know a couple friends who did the same. Wasn't a huge hassle at all with regards to logistics. I think the only things you really need to do are

1. Inform your advisor, and unless there's some weird circumstances, they'll usually say yes :)

2. On Calcentral, go to "My Academics" and click the "Withdraw" option next to the add / drop stuff in your class scheduling tab on the right.

Best of luck!!!! :)

I was looking into the option of doing that, and iirc, you do need to reapply to Berkeley to come back. The process seems simple (compared to transferring here), and you pick up right where you left off. It'll only show on your transcript as a missing semester, e.g. you'll have Spring 2020 right after Spring 2019.

^ Yeah, you would need to "reapply", but not in the traditional HS sense haha. From what I recall, it just involved signing a single piece of paper indicating you wanted to come back and handing it into your advisor. However, my memory is definitely rusty so it'd be worth it to double check :D

I see there's a cancellation and withdrawal option. Withdrawal seems like dropping out of the college. If you do cancellation, would you have to reapply to UC Berkeley and would you lose your progress/grades obtained so far?

I did that. There were some paperwork and deadline involved when I applied for readmission, but there was no real big deal. The advisor only made sure I understood that I am not allow to enroll into any 4 year college classes during my time away. They even told me that there are people who took a break since there 60s and they still can come back if they wants to. Also, there were a bunch of international students who got into Cal but needed to go back to their country to fulfill military service.

In short, Internships are valuable. Go for it.

history.content: Will there be any detrimental effects if I decide to pursue an internship during the fall instead of attending classes? I see on Berkeley's website that cancellation is possible, but are there any consequences, if any?
history.subject: What will happen if I decide to take a gap semster (i.e. fall internship)?
